key_insight: Skyra uses a multimodal LLM to detect AI-generated videos by identifying and reasoning about human-perceivable visual artifacts, producing both a detection decision and grounded, human-readable explanations.
problem_solved: Existing video detectors mostly give binary labels without localized, interpretable evidence; Skyra fills the gap by providing artifact-based, explainable detection that humans can inspect and verify.
method: Train/fine-tune a multimodal large language model to recognize and name visual artifacts (e.g., temporal flicker, lip-sync errors, inconsistent textures) from frame sequences and short clips.
Perform grounded artifact reasoning: localize artifacts in space/time, aggregate evidence across frames, and produce natural-language explanations that cite specific frames/regions as proof.
Combine artifact taxonomy, temporal consistency checks, and confidence scoring to produce a final detection verdict along with interpretable, frame-level evidence.
impact: Skyra enables more trustworthy, actionable AI-generated video detection for practitioners and forensic analysts by turning opaque binary decisions into verifiable, human-understandable evidence — improving auditability and intervention workflows.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: input video → frame extractor → artifact recognizer (MLLM) → evidence aggregator → verdict + explanation
Annotated example frames: original vs. generated with highlighted artifacts (boxes/arrows) and short textual explanations
Bar chart/table: detection accuracy vs. baseline binary classifiers and an explanation-quality metric
Timeline visualization: temporal aggregation of artifact confidence across frames to show how evidence accumulates
paper_title: Skyra: AI-Generated Video Detection via Grounded Artifact Reasoning
paper_authors: Yifei Li, Wenzhao Zheng, Yanran Zhang, Runze Sun, Yu Zheng
